resource.chars:
Anteriorly is the organ (Fig 10.10.) analogous to the ‘ciliated 
fossa’ of the Salpae - and behind this came 
a series of tongue shaped eminences (fig 1 (f) projecting 
into the respiratory cavity - and analogous 
to the “languet “ of the Salpae 
The “ciliated fossa” is compressed laterally 
and placed upon the upper surface of a protuberance 
formed by the neutral wall of the respiratory cavity 
in the middle line - On each side a flattened 
ciliated band (Fig 10.x) runs up on the respiratory wall 
in front of the anterior edge of the branchiae
and meets above with its fellow of the 
opposite side 
The “languets” are altogether eight 
in number. They extend in a longitudinal 
series between the ciliated fossa and 
the mouth - They are all slightly excavated 
and ciliated anteriorly -
Immediately beneath the ciliated fossa 
and in the midst of the ventral sinus, lies 
the ganglion - This is about 1/140 in. long, somewhat eggshaped 
with its large end forwards - Its posterior 
[text?] is in contact with a mass of deep 
red otolithes (Fig 10.d.). 
A small nerve runs from the ganglion to the 
lateral ciliated band - Five or six branches 
are distributed to the anterior aperture 
and two principal branches run backward 
to the posterior aperture giving off branches to 
the mouth in their course -

fossa’ of the Salpae - and behind this came 
a series of tongue shaped eminences (fig 1 (f) projecting

ciliated band (Fig 10.x) runs up on the respiratory wall

opposite side

Immediately beneath the ciliated fossa 
and in the midst of the ventral sinus, lies

red otolithes (Fig 10.d.). 
A small nerve runs from the ganglion to the 
lateral ciliated band - Five or six branches 
are distributed to the anterior aperture 
and two principal branches run backward 
to the posterior aperture giving off branches to 
the mouth in their course -
